abstract.p: Letter from Carl Herr says May 8 article on later problems of most premature babies should have addressed social stigma and isolation that person with disability faces in this society

block.p: ''As the Tiniest Babies Grow, So Can Their Problems'' (front page, May 8) makes some assumptions that potentially support a disturbing viewpoint.

It is not disabilities alone that ''can keep children from living independently, or ever having a social life or being able to function in society,'' as you quote a specialist as saying, but the social stigma and isolation a person with a disability faces in our society.
''As the Tiniest Babies Grow, So Can Their Problems'' (front page, May 8) makes some assumptions that potentially support a disturbing viewpoint.

It is not disabilities alone that ''can keep children from living independently, or ever having a social life or being able to function in society,'' as you quote a specialist as saying, but the social stigma and isolation a person with a disability faces in our society.

Withholding care promotes an ideology that life is not worth living for a person based on the fact that he or she has a disability, regardless of whether it is judged objectively, using medical criteria, to be ''severe.''
Let's cherish life for what it is and start talking about people, not tragedies.
The writer is a disability rights advocate at the Queens Independent Living Center.
